foods.description: Açorda is a typical dish of Portuguese cuisine, especially popular in Alentejo and Algarve. It consists of a thick soup of breadcrumbs, garlic, coriander, olive oil and hot water, to which you can add different ingredients such as seafood, fish, egg or meat. It is comforting and tasty, perfect for cold days or as a main dish on any occasion.

Alheira is a traditional Portuguese sausage, whose original recipe comes from the Jewish community in Portugal. It is made with meat, bread, garlic, and spices, usually smoked for preservation. It is grilled, fried or roasted and is often served with fried eggs, potatoes or vegetables. It is a tasty and versatile dish that is an important part of Portuguese gastronomy.

Cabidela rice is a traditional Portuguese dish consisting of rice cooked in a stew of meat, typically chicken, which has been previously marinated in a sauce of blood from the chicken cooked with vinegar and spices. This gives the dish a characteristic dark color. It is a tasty and comforting dish, much appreciated in Portuguese cuisine.

Caldo verde is a traditional Portuguese soup from the Minho region. It is prepared with green cabbage cut into thin strips, potatoes, onion, garlic and spicy sausage, all cooked in a chicken or pork soup stock. It is served hot, often accompanied by slices of bread. It is a comforting dish, especially during the colder months.

Cozido à portuguesa is a dish consisting of a stew of meats and vegetables. It is prepared by cooking a variety of meats such as pork, beef, chicken and sausages such as spicy sausage and morcela, along with vegetables such as cabbage, carrots, potatoes and turnips, all slowly cooked in an aromatic broth. It is a hearty and comforting dish, perfect for sharing at family gatherings or holidays.

The francesinha is a dish originating from the city of Oporto. It is composed of several layers of sausages such as ham, sausages, grilled meat, all wrapped in a thick slice of bread. It is then topped with melted cheese and a spicy tomato and beer based sauce. It is an indulgent and hearty delight, perfect for meat lovers and intense flavors.

Leitão is a particularly popular dish in the Bairrada region. It consists of a whole roasted suckling pig, seasoned with salt and often accompanied by pepper sauce, orange and/or aromatic herbs. The tender and juicy meat, with a crispy skin, is the delight of Portuguese cuisine lovers and a unique gastronomic experience.

Pastel de Belém, also known as Pastel de Nata, is a traditional Portuguese custard tart. It features a crispy, flaky pastry filled with a rich, creamy egg custard and is typically sprinkled with cinnamon and powdered sugar. Originating from the Belém district of Lisbon, these tarts are a beloved dessert in Portugal.

Pastel de Bacalhau is a traditional Portuguese codfish fritter. Made with a mixture of salted cod, potatoes, onions, parsley, and eggs, the mixture is deep-fried until golden and crispy. These fritters are a popular appetizer or snack, enjoyed for their savory flavor and delightful texture.
restaurants: casa Portuguesa do Patel de Bacalhau (Porto/Lisboa),

foods.description: Queijo da Serra is a traditional cheese made from sheep's milk in the Serra da Estrela region. This artisanal cheese is known for its creamy, buttery texture and strong, complex flavor, often enjoyed spread on bread or as part of a cheese platter. It is considered one of Portugal's finest and most esteemed cheeses.
restaurants: Solar do Queijo da Serra (Celorico da Beira)

foods.description: Sardinhas Assadas, or grilled sardines, is a popular Portuguese dish typically enjoyed during summer festivals. Fresh sardines are seasoned with coarse salt and grilled over charcoal, giving them a smoky, savory flavor. They are often served with boiled potatoes, salad, and a drizzle of olive oil.

Tripas, or Tripas à Moda do Porto, is a traditional dish originating from Porto. It consists of tripe stewed with white beans, sausage, and various cuts of meat, all seasoned with garlic, onions, and spices. This hearty and flavorful dish reflects the rich culinary heritage of the region.

This dish consists of a thick bechamel dough mixed with ingredients such as Iberian ham, chicken or cod, which is then coated in breadcrumbs and fried until golden brown and crispy. They are popular as a tapa in bars and restaurants throughout Spain.

The espeto de sardinas is a typical dish of Malaga cuisine consisting of sardines skewered on reeds and grilled over wood embers, usually on the beach. It is a symbol of the coastal gastronomy of Andalusia and is commonly served in 'chiringuitos' (beach bars).
Fabada asturiana is a traditional Asturian stew made with fabes (white beans), chorizo, blood sausage, bacon and other pork products. It is a hearty and tasty dish, ideal for the cold months.
Gazpacho is a cold soup originally from Andalusia, made with tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers, onion, garlic, olive oil, vinegar and bread. It is refreshing and nutritious, perfect for hot summer days.

Iberian ham is a type of high-quality cured ham produced in Spain from Iberian breed pigs. Characterized by its delicate flavor and smooth texture, it is considered a delicacy and is often served in thin slices as a tapa or appetizer.

Paella is a traditional dish from the Valencian Community in Spain, consisting of rice cooked with broth and accompanied by a variety of ingredients such as seafood, chicken, rabbit, vegetables and saffron. It is cooked in a wide, shallow pan, known as a paella pan.

Tumaca bread, or bread with tomato, is a typical Catalan dish consisting of slices of bread rubbed with ripe tomato, seasoned with olive oil and salt. It is often accompanied with cured ham or sausages, and is served as breakfast, tapa or side dish.

Papas arrugadas are a traditional dish from the Canary Islands, made with small potatoes cooked in water with lots of salt until the skin wrinkles. They are served with mojo picón, a typical Canarian sauce made with red peppers, garlic, cumin, olive oil and vinegar, which provides a spicy and distinctive flavor.

Cachopo is an Asturian dish consisting of two veal fillets breaded and stuffed with ham and cheese, which are fried until golden brown and crispy. It is often served with fried potatoes, peppers and salad, being a dish known for its strength and flavor.

Churros are a popular sweet of Spanish origin, consisting of a dough of wheat flour and water, fried in oil until crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. They are served sprinkled with sugar and often accompanied by hot chocolate for dipping. They are a classic breakfast or snack in Spain.

Patatas bravas are an especially popular dish as a tapa. They consist of potatoes cut into cubes, previously fried, which are accompanied by a spicy sauce, known as salsa brava, made with tomato, paprika, garlic, and sometimes other spices. It is a tasty and hearty dish, perfect for sharing with friends or as a side dish.

Galician style octopus is a traditional dish from Galicia, consisting of cooked octopus cut in thick slices, accompanied by boiled potatoes, olive oil, paprika and coarse salt. It is a simple recipe but full of flavor, where the protagonist is the tender and tasty octopus, very appreciated in Galician and Spanish gastronomy in general.
